title: Rondevlei Nature Reserve
text:
The Rondevlei Nature Reserve is located in <a href="Grassy%20Park">Grassy Park</a>, <a href="Zeekoevlei">Zeekoevlei</a> and Lavenderhill, <a href="suburb">suburbs</a> of <a href="Cape%20Town">Cape Town</a>, <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a>. The <a href="bird">bird</a> <a href="Animal%20Sanctuary">sanctuary</a> covers approximately of mostly permanent <a href="Cape%20Lowland%20Freshwater%20Wetland">wetland</a> and consists of a single large <a href="brackish">brackish</a> <a href="lagoon">lagoon</a>. The <a href="nature%20reserve">nature reserve</a> is among the most important wetlands for birds in South Africa despite being situated directly alongside the <a href="Zeekoevlei">Zeekoevlei</a>. A number of islands on the vlei act as vital <a href="Mating">breeding</a> sites. Rondevlei is home to about 230 bird <a href="species">species</a>, a variety of small mammals and reptiles like <a href="caracal">caracal</a>, <a href="porcupine">porcupine</a>, Cape <a href="fox">fox</a>, grysbuck, steenbuck and <a href="mongoose">mongoose</a>, as well as a <a href="hippopotamus">hippopotamus</a> <a href="population">population</a> which was re-introduced in 1981 as a means to control an <a href="Alien%20%28biology%29">alien</a> <a href="grass">grass</a> species from <a href="South%20America">South America</a>, which had covered the <a href="shoreline">shoreline</a> and was threatening to engulf the vlei itself. It boasts unusual and threatened <a href="ecosystems">ecosystems</a> like <a href="Cape%20Flats%20Dune%20Strandveld">strandveld</a>, <a href="Cape%20Flats%20Sand%20Fynbos">sand plains fynbos</a>, <a href="Cape%20Lowland%20Freshwater%20Wetland">Cape lowland wetland vegetation</a> and <a href="Endemic%20%28ecology%29">indigenous</a> coastal fynbos <a href="vegetation">vegetation</a> with unique plants found nowhere else in the world.
In February 2004, a young hippo named Hugo or Houdini escaped from Rondevlei after it was <a href="bullied">bullied</a> by an older <a href="Dominance%20hierarchy">dominant</a> male and was on the run for 10 months until it was caught in December and moved to an <a href="Eastern%20Cape">Eastern Cape</a> private reserve.
History.
The reserve was established in 1952 in cooperation with the Cape Divisional Council (now Cape Metropolitan Council), when the area was still used by locals to graze <a href="horse">horse</a>s and <a href="cattle">cattle</a>, for woodcutting and flower picking. Originally it consisted of the vlei and about of land, which was extended in 1963 and 1987 by adding <a href="dunes">dunes</a> and seasonal wetlands to the south of the vlei to the reserve. To prevent <a href="flooding">flooding</a> of the built-up areas, which contained then mainly sub-economic housing, a <a href="dam">dam</a> at the south-eastern end of the vlei was built to permanently lower the level of Rondevlei. The management of the reserve was taken over by the South Peninsula <a href="Municipality">Municipality</a> in 1997 and it is now part of the <a href="City%20of%20Cape%20Town">City of Cape Town</a>.
Facilities.
The facilities in the reserve include an about long waterside <a href="trail">trail</a> along the <a href="shoreline">shoreline</a> with six bird hides and two large wooden observation towers, a <a href="terrarium">terrarium</a> and <a href="aquarium">aquarium</a>, as well as the Leonard Gill museum and an <a href="Environmentalism">environmental</a> education centre with lecture theater and resource centre.
Besides <a href="birdwatching">birdwatching</a> visitors are offered guided tours, boat cruises, conference facilities and secluded overnight accommodation within the reserve which are organized by a community-based company, Imvubu Nature Tours, which was established in 2002 with the use of poverty relief funds, made available by the Department of Environmental Affairs and Tourism.
